section.title: Continuously Payable Annuities
section.p: A continuously payable annuity is an annuity where the payment is "smeared out" over time. The payment is then quoted as a rate, such as K per year or K per month. These come up rarely on the FM exam, but are covered here for completion.

To match the interest rate period with the payment period, we use the continuous compounding rate. This is the (constant) force of interest \delta. The notation for future and present value are \overline{s}_{\angln \iota} and \overline{a}_{\angln \iota}.

introduction.p: Since our payments are "smeared out" we can think of this as taking payments of \frac{1}{m} m times per year, and then take the limit as m\to\infty.

task.p: If the effective annual rate is \iota, what is the effective m-times a year rate?
Using your effective m-times a year rate, what would be the future value of an annuity which pays \frac{1}{m} m times a year for n years?
The denominator of your fraction is m((1+\iota)^{\frac{1}{m}} -1). What is the limit as m\to\infty? Hint: Use L'Hopital's rule - this is of the form \infty - \infty.
Using your work above, fill in a formula for \overline{s}_{\angln \iota} and guess a formula for \overline{a}_{\angln \iota}. The derivation for \overline{a}_{\angln \iota} follows the same process.

statement.p: Rewrite the formulas for \overline{a}_{\angln} and \overline{s}_{\angln} so that both the numerators and denominators are in terms of \delta. Which do you like better?
Find the present value of a continuously payable annuity, with payments at a rate of 12,000 per year for 5 years, assuming \delta = 0.05.
There is 40,000 in a fund which is accumulating at 4% per annum convertible continuously. If money is withdrawn continuously at a rate of 2400 per annum, how long will the fund last?
